text: Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For? Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm.

text: Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well. Patient: Yeah. I feel great. It’s just the energy. Doctor: Yes. (keyboarding sounds) Patient: Wednesdays are fine. Doctor: That works better for you. Patient: Yes. text: Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Patient: Well, huh, a doctor from Johns Hopkins two weeks ago worked on a girl, gave her this medicine, and everything disappeared. It’s in the paper. Doctor: But she didn’t have prostate cancer. text: Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

text: Patient: Um. Doctor: Did, uh, did she get tested for it? Family Member: She did not get tested, but Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But, uh, E_’s gonna want to know. Patient: My daughter who just had this, our third grandson, would, I’m sure would want to know. Family Member: I’m sure for E_. Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
